title: Kyle Saunders Intro Responses

code-activity: C++. Learning C++ we would always start by putting in order: author, date, filename, purpose, error checking, assumptions and input/output. We would also document majority of code with comments to give the user an understanding of what exactly each part of code is doing.
screencast-experience: I have made videos in the past using just things like iMovie, Windows Movie Maker, a little Sony Vegas 8 for various high school videos for classes. A previous english class I used vocaroo to record my voice only for some parts of projects.
screengrab-experience: Not really, most of the time if I need a picture for a powerpoint slide or any project that I've encountered so far, I can just find it on google images. I have plenty of screenshot programs such as Gyazo, Greenshot and Puush, though.
documentation-thoughts: For me specifically since I'm a programmer it would be something like, leaving information for yourself or others to use when engaging with your project/program/app or whatever it may be.
learning-objectives: How to better document things so people can understand them better, maybe get in some better habits. Not really too sure, so I'll just say a lot!
title: Spencer Backus Intro Responses

code-activity: I know C/C++, Java, HTML, CSS, CSS Preporcessors, JavaScript, SQL, PL/SQL, PHP, XML, R, but right now at my internship I mostly use HTML, PHP, JavaScript and CSS. Right now the main technique I use is commenting something if it's kind of hard to trace or read, and if I used code from somewhere else to give credit and not plagiarize.
screengrab-experience: On Windows, there is 'snipping tool', and that's what I use. On Mac I use Command-Shift-4.
operating-systems: Windows, Mac OSX, iOS (iPhone, iPad), Android, Linux / Ubuntu / Other flavors of Unix
documentation-thoughts: When it comes to code, I think a few things. 1. I think of commenting and describing in english what happens so the next person to read the code can better understand it. 2. I think of uploading the latest working version to github and in the README.md writing vital things to know, along with changes from the last version.
learning-objectives: Better ways to document code so that the next person can flawlessly take over what I was working on.
title: Anthony Albertina Intro Responses

code-activity:
Lately, I have been doing web development and writing configuration scripts for OS and software deployments in IT environments.  I can and will use any tool the job requires. As a result of this agnosticism, I have used Javascript, Python, Ruby, PHP, C, C++, HTML, CSS, .BAT scripts, Powershell, SASS, and probably some other technologies I'm forgetting about.
    I'm a big fan of simplistic and self-documenting code, but I will also sprinkle comments around. I haven't really collaborated with large teams or maintained projects for extended periods, so my style is still evolving.
screencast-experience: I have never made videos or screencasts, although I considered writing for Digital Ocean despite being totally unqualified.
screengrab-experience: I use Shutter on Linux for screenshots.
operating-systems: Windows, Mac OSX, Android, Linux / Ubuntu / Other flavors of Unix
documentation-thoughts: The readme in a GitHub repo or the the act of clicking on the 'Documentation' link on the page of whatever technology I'm trying to use in any given moment.
learning-objectives: I hope to gain enough knowledge to consider my ability to author documentation as a valuable and marketable skill. That being said, I do not want to be the "documentation guy."
title: Derek Baker Intro Responses

learning-objectives: Umm... get credit for an upper division writing course?  New ways to explain how
